DataElement.preferredName: Thyroid Cancer American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) Edition 7 Pathologic Distant Metastasis M Stage
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Extent of the distant metastasis for the thyroid tumor based on evidence obtained from pathologic examination through completion of definitive surgery.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Thyroid Gland Neoplasm Pathologic M Stage
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: An endocrine gland located at the base of the neck that produces and secretes thyroxine and other hormones. Thyroxine is important for metabolic control._A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation.  Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia.  Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias._Caused by or altered by or manifesting disease or pathology._One criteria of the TMN staging system.  M refers to the presence of metastasis.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: An endocrine gland located at the base of the neck that produces and secretes thyroxine and other hormones. Thyroxine is important for metabolic control.:A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.

Concepts.definition: An endocrine gland located at the base of the neck that produces and secretes thyroxine and other hormones. Thyroxine is important for metabolic control.

A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.

Property.preferredDefinition: Pathologic; caused by or altered by or manifesting disease or pathology.:One criteria of the TMN staging system.  M refers to the presence of metastasis.

Concepts.definition: Caused by or altered by or manifesting disease or pathology.
One criteria of the TNM staging system. M refers to the presence of metastasis.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

DataElementConcept.changeDescription: Created for CRF standard harmonization. Released per final community approval. mc 5/7/12

ValueDomain.preferredName: Thyroid Cancer American Joint Committee on Cancer Stage (AJCC) Edition 7 Pathologic M Stage
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A pathologic finding about one or more characteristics of thyroid cancer, following the rules of the TNM AJCC v7 classification system as they pertain to distant metastases.  There is no pathologic M0 for thyroid cancer._A group formed for the purpose of developing a system of clinical staging for cancer that is acceptable to the American medical profession and is compatible with other accepted classifications._The extent of a cancer within the body, especially whether the disease has spread from the original site to other parts of the body.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Thyroid cancer with distant metastasis. (from AJCC 6th and 7th Eds.)

Concepts.longName: Thyroid Cancer pM1 TNM Finding v6 and v7
Concepts.definition: Thyroid cancer with distant metastasis. (from AJCC 6th and 7th Eds.)

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

There is no pathologic M0 for thyroid cancer.:A group formed for the purpose of developing a system of clinical staging for cancer that is acceptable to the American medical profession and is compatible with other accepted classifications.:The extent of a cancer within the body, especially whether the disease has spread from the original site to other parts of the body.

Concepts.longName: Thyroid Cancer Pathologic Distant Metastasis TNM Finding v7
Concepts.definition: A pathologic finding about one or more characteristics of thyroid cancer, following the rules of the TNM AJCC v7 classification system as they pertain to distant metastases.  There is no pathologic M0 for thyroid cancer.
A group formed for the purpose of developing a system of clinical staging for cancer that is acceptable to the American medical profession and is compatible with other accepted classifications.
The extent of a cancer in the body.
